data.message:
I'm doing a lot of looking up actors therefor I gave the actors an Id

And stored them in a Dict with their id as the key

Instead of as a list
I did the same for components which makes updating a certain component easier

And I really often need to search actors by a position

Therefor I created indices which are dicts from position to actor id

Now all of these changes are to minimize the time needed searching for actors

A dict loopup is faster then iterating over a large list

An other way to optimize performance is to not give "update ticks" to all actors

In the main loop I'm only updating actors which are in the view and some additional actors just outside the view

To `update` even less actors
 Actors are split into two types. Static actors and dynamic actors

Where the difference is that dynamic actors hold components that needs update ticks

While static actors does not.

In the boulder game things like dirt and wall are static. While rocks and the hero are dynamic actors
This is somewhere inside the game loop where I'm only getting actors which are dynamic

Another performance optimization is that I'm not actually creating the view, when the view method of elm gets called

This view will get called by "the elm engine" every time that the model changes

But I know that certain messages do not change the game state and therefor not the visual output

Messages like key inputs

Therefor I create the view myself whenever I know it changed and store that as part of my model.

To be clear this happens in the elm `update` function

And the last one, if someone comes up with a faster implementation for an operation you use a lot

Then you proudly copy his implementation for your game

To close I would like to share the toughest lesson learned which was most definitely keeping track of what your "newest" actor/level or model is

I have had a few times that I was like wtf is going on why is not this working

And then the conclusion was that I did not update the actor in the accumulated level and there for changes where lost etc

These are nifty bugs to find

settings.light: type: point; angle: 50; castShadow: true; color: #eee; intensity: 0.6
